result.execSummary:
The defendant Lamarr E Miller was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess w/Intent-Cocaine (>5-15g), a class E felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(cm)2.
  • Cause Injury/Operate-Control. Substance (1st) (PAC<0.15), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(2)(a)3.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Defendant IS eligible for Substance Abuse Program.
Apply 252 days sentence credit.
Concurrent with: Count 3.

superMiscConds.notes:
Cash bail applied to Court costs and DNA surcharge.  Balance to be paid as a Condition of the Sentence.

  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.
Maintain employment and/or combination of schooling.
AODA assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended.

ABSOLUTE SOBRIETY.
Submit to random urine screens.
No use or possession of alcohol, controlled substances or drug paraphernalia.
No use or possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of any and all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent.
No contact with the victims listed in the Criminal Complaint.
Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided, immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.

Lesli S Boese appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Lamarr E Miller in court, in custody (by video from Washington County Jail), with attorney Samuel W. Benedict.
Motion filed by Defense - To Admit Evidence of Untruthfullness of Law Enforcement Witness.

Atty. Benedict presented arguments to the court (Statute cited 906.08).
ADA Boese presented arguments to the court (Statute cited 904.03).
Atty. Benedict presented a response.

Court finds/orders the following:  
Court finds the officer's conduct is not unduly remote in time.
Court finds an officer's credibility is always an issue, and in this specific situation it specifically applies to his functioning as a law enforcement officer.
Court finds this is not an other acts evidence issue.
Court Grants - Defense Motion.
Court will allow for limited testimony as laid out by the defense.
Court will only allow the testimony through cross-examination of the specific officer in question; not through employment records or character witnesses/prior supervisors.
Further reasons placed on the record.

Defendant to appear by video for the next court date.
If the Washington County can't accommodated that date the court will waive the defendant's appearance.
